Confirming `tools::checkPoFile()` detects mismatched/typo in redirected templates:

```> tools::checkPoFile("po/zh_CN.po")
po/zh_CN.po:25
assign.c:12
differences in entries 1,2
Internal error: finalizer sees l=%d, tl=%d
内部错误： 结束操作(finalizer)检测到l=%1d, tl=%1d```

text:
Hi Ben, Many thanks for providing this dashboard. I'm not sure if the review should go here or via Github. But I have some questions. I see some languages in the language home report <https://contributor.r-project.org/translations/weblate/> not present in <https://contributor.r-project.org/translations/>. Is this because the source of the data is different? Also from the language in question (catalan), I don't see any information about who is translating to that language in other parts of the dashboard, perhaps the data is not in sync?
Many thanks again

text:
We wrapped up the work on the translation documentation and guidelines in the R Sprint :partyr:. After 3 days of work there’s been some great progress in many fronts:
• <@U04SYDF81D5> merged changes to the R Development Guide to include <https://contributor.r-project.org/rdevguide/message-translations.html#how-to-contribute-new-translations|instructions on using Weblate>
• We've created a wiki in the translations repo that includes:
    ◦ A <https://github.com/r-devel/translations/wiki|home> with many details, including a detailed "getting started" guide and many linked resources. 
    ◦ Overall <https://github.com/r-devel/translations/wiki/Conventions-for-translations|guidelines> for translation. Please read them carefully!
    ◦ Drafts of language-specific guidelines were started (and we hope to continue developing them after the sprint) for the languages Arabic, Hindi, Japanese, Portuguese (Br), Spanish, Bengali and Nepali
• We've set up admins and reviewers on Weblate and are now using the <https://docs.weblate.org/en/latest/workflows.html#dedicated-reviewers|dedicated reviewers workflow>, that was enabled before the sprint but didn't have any reviewers assigned. This has been done for the languages Arabic, Hindi, Japanese, Portuguese (Br), Spanish, Bengali and Nepali
Some to-dos to do language by language
• *If your language doesn't have established roles within weblate* (admin, reviewers) you can communicate with other translators to establish them. Only reviewers can approve translations, but languages without dedicated reviewers have their translations directly approved without review. To ensure consistent translations you should, when able, establish reviewer roles in your language. 
• If your language doesn't have a page with specific guidelines for it, you can also communicate with other translators to start working on them. 
Next steps
• In the next few weeks we can coordinate a meeting between translators (whether they were present in the sprint or nor) to discuss the overall direction of the project :rocket:

, that was enabled before the sprint but didn't have any reviewers assigned. This has been done for the languages Arabic, Hindi, Japanese, Portuguese (Br), Spanish, Bengali and Nepali

If your language doesn't have established roles within weblate
